prop.head.label.name: Part
prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

para.paratext: The filing of a motion for transfer has no mandatory effect on proceedings in courts where any actions subject to the motion are pending. The filing of a motion for transfer does not stay proceedings,[1] nor does the entry of an order to show cause or a conditional transfer order.[2] The Panel Rules clearly provide that Panel orders become effective when filed with the clerk of the transferee district court. Panel Rule 2.1(d) provides:

(d) Pendency of Motion or Conditional Order. The pendency of a motion, order to show cause, conditional transfer order or conditional remand order before the Panel pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 1407 does not affect or suspend orders and pretrial proceedings in any pending federal district court action and does not limit the pretrial jurisdiction of that court. An order to transfer or remand pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 1407 shall be effective only upon its filing with the clerk of the transferee district court.

The rule makes it clear that the trial court may continue to manage the pretrial proceedings in the case during the pendency of proceedings before the Panel. Rulings entered by the transferor court after a transfer motion is filed with the Panel but before the transfer order is filed are valid, and are entitled to the same deference of any other orders entered prior to transfer.[3]

The transferor court may, however, enter a stay of proceedings pending decision of the Panel. That question is directed solely to the transferor court's discretion, however.[4] The Panel has declined to consider the stay question, and has deferred to the transferor courts without any indication of how the Panel would view the merits of the stay request.[5]

In denying centralization, the Panel may suggest that a stay of later-filed actions may be a worthwhile alternative to transfer.[6] District courts have, however, readily stayed proceedings pending a Panel decision.[7] Potential transferor courts also frequently deny requests for a stay, recognizing that there is no reason to delay deciding many motions that may arise or be pending at the time possible MDL transfer comes up.[8] Indeed, in some cases the potential transferor court may view it advantageous to have an issue decided before the Panel decides the transfer issue.[9] This is especially issue where the case raises threshold issues relating to the particular facts of the case.[10] Potential transferor courts have also recognized that the mere filing of a motion with the Panel does not prevent the other parties with proceeding with filing motions in the transferor court.[11] The mere prospect of transfer proceedings before the Panel may prompt a trial court to abstain from the exercise of jurisdiction.[12] As is always true for abstention decisions, in other situations a trial court may readily decline to abstain.[13]

When the court where actions are pending confronts a motion for a stay because of the pendency of a motion for centralization before the Panel, the following guidelines are typical of those followed by the court.

When considering a motion to stay a case pending a motion to the JPML to transfer and consolidate, the district court should consider three factors: (1) potential prejudice to the non-moving party; (2) hardship and inequity to the moving party if the action is not stayed; and (3) the judicial resources that would be saved by avoiding duplicative litigation if the cases are in fact consolidated.[14]

As a practical matter, the fact of a pending motion for transfer under section 1407, or the threat of such a motion, presents the trial judge with a fairly simple decision. The Manual for Complex Litigation provides some insight into the judge's considerations—although pending motions should generally be decided and additional motions may be filed, the judge will probably want to defer decisions on matters relating to long-term case management.[15] As is true for many decisions directed to the trial court's discretion, the court's view on these issues will probably be affected by the judge's assessment of the likelihood of transfer being ordered by the Panel. Deferral of ruling on motions may be particularly unlikely if it is likely that the MDL docket may be sent to that judge or district.
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.

See, e.g., General Elec. Co. v. Byrne, 611 F.2d 670 (7th Cir. 1979); General Tire & Rubber Co. v. Jefferson Chemical Co., 50 F.R.D. 112 (S.D. N.Y. 1970); In re Frost Patent, 316 F. Supp. 977, 978 n.2 (J.P.M.L. 1970.)

See, e.g., General Elec. Co. v. Byrne, 611 F.2d 670 (7th Cir. 1979). Conditional transfer orders are authorized by Panel R. 9. The Panel Rules are reprinted in § 4:34. The use of a conditional transfer order in “tag-along” actions is discussed in §§ 4:24 and 8:3.
See, e.g., In re Yasmin and Yaz (Drospirenone) Marketing, Sales Practices and Products Liability Litigation, 2011 WL 2746086 (S.D. Ill. 2011).

Lafoy v. Volkswagen Group of America, Inc., 2016 WL 2733161 (E.D. Mo. 2016); Beshear v. Volkswagen Group of America, Inc., 2016 WL 3040492 (E.D. Ky. 2016); Adams v. Bristol-Meyers Squibb Co., 2016 WL 4257595 (D. Colo. 2016) (court grants unopposed motion for stay pending Panel decision); In re Honda of America Mfg., Inc. ERISA Fees Litigation, 2009 WL 700696 (S.D. Ohio 2009) (denying stay). See also Louisiana Stadium and Exposition Dist. v. Financial Guar. Ins. Co., 2009 WL 926982 (E.D. La. 2009) (exercising discretion to grant stay pending Panel decision on transfer); Tolley v. Monsanto Co., 591 F. Supp. 2d 837 (S.D. W. Va. 2008) (reviewing reasons for exercise of discretion to proceed with motion to remand to state court); see generally Patricia Howard, A Guide to Multidistrict Litigation, 75 F.R.D. 577, 582 (1978).
See, e.g., In re Air Crash Disaster at Paris, France, on March 3, 1974, 376 F. Supp. 887, 888 (J.P.M.L. 1974). See generally Manual for Complex Litigation Fourth § 22.35 (2004).

See In re: Uber Technologies, Inc., Telephone Consumer Protection Act (Tcpa) Litigation, 247 F. Supp. 3d 1386 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2016); In re Quaker Oats Maple & Brown Sugar Instant Oatmeal Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 190 F. Supp. 3d 1349, 1351 & n.4 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2016).

See, e.g., Royal Park Investments SA/NV v. Bank of America Corp., 941 F. Supp. 2d 367 (S.D. N.Y. 2013) (stay following entry of conditional transfer order, pending final resolution of transfer); Curtis v. BP America, Inc., 808 F. Supp. 2d 976 (S.D. Tex. 2011) (analyzing standard); Reichert v. Mark Starring and Associates, Inc., 2011 WL 5078279 (E.D. La. 2011); Hoy v. I-Flow Corp., 2010 WL 743561 (D. Colo. 2010); Bigley v. Sgarlato Laboratories, Inc., 2010 WL 743587 (D. Colo. 2010); Giles v. POM Wonderful LLC, 2010 WL 4630325 (S.D. Fla. 2010); Bonenfant v. R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Co., 2007 WL 2409980 (S.D. Fla. 2007); Republic of Venezuela ex rel. Garrido v. Philip Morris Cos., Inc., 1999 WL 33911677 (S.D. Fla. 1999); In re Four Seasons Securities Litigation, 344 F. Supp. 1404, 1405 (J.P.M.L. 1972) (Panel noted that district court had continued hearing on discovery motion pending Panel decision on transfer); but see Gilmore v. DJO Inc., 2010 WL 1050535 (D. Ariz. 2010) (stay denied); Collier v. SmithKline Beecham, 2010 WL 2990014 (S.D. Ill. 2010) (stay denied); Wells v. Toyota Motor Sales USA, Inc., 2010 WL 1856012 (S.D. Ill. 2010) (stay denied).
See, e.g., Sullivan v. Cottrell, Inc., 2012 WL 694825 (W.D.N.Y. 2012).
See, e.g., Sherfey v. Volkswagen Group of America, Inc., 2016 WL 1741254 (N.D. Ohio 2016) (denying stay and granting motion to remand for lack of subject matter jurisdiction).
Manual for Complex Litigation (Fourth) § 20.131 (2004).
See, e.g., U.S. ex rel. Cosens v. St. Francis Hosp., 241 F. Supp. 2d 223 (E.D. N.Y. 2002).
In re Pan Am Corp., 128 B.R. 59 (S.D. N.Y. 1991), aff'd in part, rev'd in part on other grounds, 950 F.2d 839 (2d Cir. 1991).
In re WorldCom, Inc. Securities Litigation, 293 B.R. 308 (S.D. N.Y. 2003).

Curtis v. BP America, Inc., 808 F. Supp. 2d 976 (S.D. Tex. 2011); Rivers v. Walt Disney Co., 980 F. Supp. 1358, 1360 (C.D. Cal. 1997) citing American Seafood, Inc. v. Magnolia Processing, Inc., 1992 WL 102762, at *1-2 (E.D. Pa. 1992)). See also Jozwiak v. Stryker Corp., 2010 WL 147143 (M.D. Fla. 2010).

Manual for Complex Litigation Fourth § 20.132 (2004). For an example of this more nuanced approach to the stay question, see Strumlauf v. Starbucks Corp., 2016 WL 3645194 (N.D. Cal. 2016) (partial stay ordered, allowing initial discovery to proceed but staying the taking of any depositions).
